The task in the rst half of the course is to introduce Lebesgue measure and establish properties of the Lebesgue integral. Our textbook (Adams and Guillemin) introduces Lebesgue measure using motivation and examples from probability theory. An equally important motivation (that will only become clear in the second half) is that the systematic study of Fourier series requires the Lebesgue integral. The square mean convergence of Fourier series and Parsevals formula cannot be stated accurately in proper generality without the Lebesgue integral and Lebesgue integrable functions f(x). Probability theory. A Bernoulli sequence is an innite sequence of outcomes HTTHTTTH of coin tosses with H representing heads and T representing tails. Assume that heads and tails are equally likely and that the tosses are independent of each other. Then the 8-letter initial sequence displayed has probability 28 as does each of the 28 possible words of length 8 in the letters H and T . The rst paradox we face is that the probability of any single innite string is zero (the limit of 2n as n ), whereas if we add up all possibilities we get 0 = 1 ?? It turns out that this paradox is a real contradiction that has to be avoided. The collection of outcomes is uncountably innite. (This is proved by the Cantor diagonal argument and is the subject of our rst homework exercise.) We will have to give up on sums of probabilities with uncountably many terms. Given that some operations are illegal, our job will be to gure out what operations are legal and give meaningful probability values. Fortunately there are many meaningful questions we can answer. For n 0, consider Sn = number of heads minus number of tails in rst n tosses The trajectory of Sn is known as a random walk (in one dimension, that is, on the integers Z). I graphed this for the example HTTHTTTH : S0 = 0, S1 = 1, S2 = 0, S3 = 1, etc. A statement referring to full, innite strings can only make sense using a correct formulation 2

After we have developed probability theory on Bernoulli sequences, using a correspondence with Lebesgue measure on the unit interval, we will discuss the Lebesgue integral and some Fourier analysis. Then we will use some Fourier analysis to prove more theorems in probability. By the end of the semester we will have all the tools to discuss the continuum limit of a (suitably scaled) random walk, namely Brownian motion. The rst rigorous formulation of Brownian motion was given by Norbert Wiener (in the math department at MIT in the 1920s) before probability theory itself was on a fully rigorous footing! Brownian motion starting from B(0) = 0 is given on 0 t by sin kt B(t) = a0t + ak k k=1 where the ak, k = 1, 2,... are independent, standard (mean 0, variance 1) normal random variables. (The coecient a0 is also a normal random variable, but with a dierent variance, which we will gure out later. In lecture, for simplicity, I omitted a0 initially. Without the a0t term, B(t) returns to 0 at t = and is known as a Brownian bridge.) Wiener showed that with probability 1, B(t) is continuous but not dierentiable. Curi ously, with the help of Fourier series representations, even non-dierentiable functions can be dierentiated. The catch is that the answer is not a function. The derivative
dB/dt = ak cos kt k=0 is known as white noise. With probability 1 the series on the right is not convergent. Although with probability 1 this series does not represent a function (much less a continuous function), it nevertheless has a good interpretation as a so-called generalized function. You have already seen one such generalized function in 18.03, namely the delta function. We will discuss generalized functions much later in the course. In Lecture 2, we will begin the systematic theory of Lebesgue measure, starting with the case of the unit interval, in tandem with probability theory for Bernoulli sequences, following the Adams-Guillemin text. 3
